headline.main: Scientists Debate China's Law on Sterilizing the Carriers of Genetic Defects

docs.snippet: In an unusual move, the 2,000 scientists gathered here this week for the 18th International Congress of Genetics took time out from discussions of cloning and cancer genes to confront a controversial Chinese law, one that many experts believe permits
docs.lead_paragraph: In an unusual move, the 2,000 scientists gathered here this week for the 18th International Congress of Genetics took time out from discussions of cloning and cancer genes to confront a controversial Chinese law, one that many experts believe permits doctors to require that people with serious genetic conditions be sterilized. In several forums and even at the closing ceremonies, some of the world's foremost geneticists scrutinized, and sometimes criticized, the vaguely worded 1994 law, debating whether it intended to condone forced sterilization or was just so poorly worded that it left that option open.

headline.main: A Spectacular Tale In Its Mythic Home; 'Turandot' Enters the Forbidden City

docs.lead_paragraph: In a giant courtyard of the Forbidden City, a woman's voice soars gloriously into the night sky. Spotlights illuminate a 580-year-old Ming Dynasty temple where emperors once made sacrifices to their ancestors. Now hundreds of Chinese soldiers and dancers move to the music and to instructions shouted over a loudspeaker. Two ancient-looking pavilions at the front of the vermilion temple hall eerily glide toward center stage, then spew forth dozens more soldiers.

headline.main: 'Turandot' Bids Farewell To Beijing, the 'Home' It Awed and Perplexed

docs.snippet: After eight  performances  actually seven and two-thirds, because one was halted by rain -- the much-anticipated production of ''Turandot'' in an ancient temple of the Forbidden City here  closed on Sunday night to a lengthy  standing ovation from a
docs.lead_paragraph: After eight performances actually seven and two-thirds, because one was halted by rain -- the much-anticipated production of ''Turandot'' in an ancient temple of the Forbidden City here closed on Sunday night to a lengthy standing ovation from a nearly full house approaching 3,000. If the sumptuous costumes, lavish set and kinetic staging by the Chinese movie director Zhang Yimou sometimes seemed to upstage the music -- conducted by Zubin Mehta with singing by major stars -- the thousands of opera fanatics who traveled here from Europe, the United States and neighboring Asian countries still got what they paid for: a grand theatrical spectacle that will be hard to match.

headline.main: U.N. Rights Official, Back From China, Sees Better Attitude

docs.snippet: At the end of what she called ''a successful but not always easy first visit to China,'' the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, Mary Robinson,  said today that despite continuing human rights abuses, she had sensed among Chinese leade
docs.lead_paragraph: At the end of what she called ''a successful but not always easy first visit to China,'' the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, Mary Robinson, said today that despite continuing human rights abuses, she had sensed among Chinese leaders a new willingness to discuss the country's rights record. Mrs. Robinson said she had been told by Chinese officials that they were prepared to sign the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights next month. She said the Chinese Government had also signed a letter of understanding with the Human Rights Commission requesting technical assistance in resolving human rights issues.

docs.lead_paragraph: As the crowd of mostly young Beijingers filed in from the misty night off Tiananmen Square, it was obvious this was not your everyday world film premiere. Sure, there were cameras flashing, huge movie posters and a high proportion of men with ponytails. But instead of a red carpet, there were metal detectors and X-ray security machines. And weren't those bouncers People's Liberation Army guards?

headline.main: Beijing Journal; Tide of Traffic Turns Against the Sea of Bicycles

docs.lead_paragraph: Every day this city's wide boulevards are marred by a million ugly battles between ''gas vehicles,'' as cars are called in Chinese, and ''self-propelled vehicles,'' a.k.a. bicycles. Although sturdy bicycles remain the primary transportation for the vast majority of Beijingers, their powerful gas-guzzling cousins have been multiplying rapidly, literally edging cyclists off the road.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re your Nov. 3 Beijing Journal on cars replacing bicycles as the primary mode of transportation in that city: The economic think tanks can now start telling us how much these expensive (by local standards) vehicles have contributed to China's gross domestic product and hence to its economic development. To the man in the street, however, the quality of life is deteriorating. But who listens to him?
